subject: Ethics
title: Germline vs. Somatic Editing
description: A quick, practical guide to Germline vs. Somatic Editing.

hook.text: Fix your own broken gene? Fine. Fix it so your grandchildren inherit the edit? That's different.

buildup.text: Somatic editing changes genes in one person's body cells. The edits die with them.

discovery.text: Germline editing alters eggs, sperm, or embryosâ€”the change passes down to every future generation.

twist.text: Future generations can't consent. You're rewriting their DNA before they exist.

climax.text: Most countries ban germline editing in humans. The consequences are permanent and irreversible.

punchline.text: Editing yourself is a choice. Editing your descendants is a decree.

quiz.question: Why is germline editing considered more ethically problematic than somatic editing?
options: Changes pass to future generations who cannot consent
Germline editing is more painful for patients
Somatic editing is illegal in most countries
